												This is my first review of a game, but I though this game deserved a review as it's been getting a lot of negative reviews that are unwarranted in my opinion. I live in South Africa and have been hunting a couple of times before and it's something I enjoy. What I enjoy about hunting is that you go out into wide open spaces of beautiful nature. You have to patiently stalk your prey, following spoor (tracks), looking at their dung, checking that you're not upwind. It's not easy, and some days you can go the whole day without even getting close to having a shot at your prey.So in context of this game, I never thought I'd ever find or enjoy any hunting game that gives me the same thrill as I get in real life. But I was wrong. This game does really well in making you feel like you're in this beautiful nature reserve with some of the best graphics and sound design I've seen in a game. It really is stunning. I often just stare at a beautiful sunrise or a strong gust of wind blowing leaves off the trees around me. The beautiful world you get to play in alone is worth the asking price for this game.The actual hunting part has been done extremely well. In this game I've felt like it really is quite close to hunting in real life. Patience is key. Checking wind direction, following tracks, listening for your prey's sounds, looking at your prey's dung etc. has been really well thought out and implemented. It can take hours to find and hunt the prey you're looking for, but it feels worth it. I've seen a lot of people complain about bugs in their reviews, and I have seen a couple, but none of them were game breaking in my opinion. If that is what is holding you back from buying this game, then let me assure you, it's not that bad. The bugs aren't that major, and I have to say that it runs extremely well on my machine. My settings are all cranked up and I'm running a GeForce 970, 8GB RAM, Intel i5 2500k processor, and have experienced no lag or crashes.If you want a game to get lost in, that takes time and patience, that is beautiful and realistic, then give this a go. I hope they bring out an African map in a future DLC!

												Let's get something straight right off the top here... this is, by far, one of the most graphically beautiful simulations of an outdoor environment currently available.  Period.  I've been gaming for over 30 years, and this game, with it's accurate global illumination and sunlight simulation, is one of the most immersive experiences I've ever seen thanks to their Apex open world engine.  This is the kind of thing that the next Elder Scrolls game NEEDS, and it's almost worth the $30 price just as a walking simulator alone!  Yeah, it's THAT good.  Even the audio is fantastic... realistic bird calls, buzzing insects, breezes blowing through the trees, etc....it feels like I'm actually walking through a woodland setting.  It's awesome!Note: you need a reasonbly good PC to get all the eye candy at anything above 50-ish fps and people with lesser machines have complained about poor performance.  I can max out all details at 2560x1440 and get between 50~60 fps.  (See the bottom of my review for system specs.)But anyway, the graphics and sound goodies are where the list of awesome things about this game ends.  I really WANT to be able to recommend this game, but the rest is a mixed bag of bugs, broken features, and insanely baffling design decisions that leave me not only nearly speechless, but also more than a little♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off.  Back on release day, BluesNews.com posted an article that said that this game had been release as Early Access, but the article was in error because it was, in fact, a full release with no mention of Early Access.  However, that's EXACTLY what this game feels like, and if you haven't been to the forums or read a lot of other reviews yet, you'll see that plenty of other players say the same thing.  Normally I'm pretty forgiving of bugs and whatnot, but in this case, I just can't cut this much slack.Some bugs have been fixed with a recent patch, but it's far from enough, and some of the worst bugs still remain.  Some of those most obvious bugs involve the animal AI, which is ironic considering the fact that it's a core element to the entire purpose of the game,  For example, it's common to encounter animals that don't seem to notice the player and will stand completely still as you walk right up to them.  It's like being in a "West World" kind of place where the animals are robots and they sometimes malfunction.  They also get stuck in terrain and rocks, causing them to run in place indefinitely.The whole game has a "console-ish" feel, like it's made for kids or something, compared to Expansive Worlds' other game, theHunter Classic, which is much more comprehensive, although doesn't look as good.  Pretty much everything in the game has to be unlocked by visiting points on the map or shooting certain animals or whatever.  You have to earn cash to buy lures, ammo, weapons, and everything is laughably expensive.  I suppose this is a viable method of giving the player a reason to keep hunting, but it also lends to an "arcade-like" experience.  They claim the game went through beta "testing", but if that's true, then their beta testers were far less competent than they needed to be.  Or maybe the testers reported the bugs and the devs chose to ignore them.  Either way, most of the problems this game has are inexcusable and could not possibly have any sort of intelligent explanation as to how they made it into the final release.Other issues that drive me nuts... - Placing a waypoint on the map does NOT put a marker on your HUD or the Hunter Mate device, which requires you to keep opening the map to make sure you're heading in the right direction.  100% useless feature. - The compass is supposed to allow for "free" or "fixed" rotation, but it's always on "fixed" regardless of the setting. - The Hunter Mate randomly stops showing the track directional cones while you are tracking animals. - Keyboard & mouse players cannot move slowly which means you're always making maximum noise.  (You have to use a game controller and the analog movement stick to "sneak" successfully.) - Occassionally, a random deer or two will come out of nowhere, running in a perfectly straight line, and hit you at full speed, causing health damage as they continue off on their merry way.  Frightening. - Animal tracks sometimes double back on themselves and then disappear, even though you don't actually see the animal cross your path as the tracks indicate. - Animals often give "warning calls" to let you know that your presence has been detected by either sound, scent, or sight, even though you're A.) not making any noise, B.) down wind, and C.) visually obstructed by hundreds of meters of solid earth, otherwise known as a hill or mountain.  There's some debate as to whether or not the animals actually have the ability to detect you or perhaps their behavior is mostly random.  (It seems random to me.) - Even though the visuals are stunning, the water reflections are CRAP.  I mean, absolute garbage.  You'd have to see them to know what I mean, but I find it absurd that so much of the game's engine is so beautiful, and then they totally ♥♥♥♥ up the water reflection shader.  The water looks much better if you just turn off the reflections.  Not as realistic, no, but still acceptable. - Rain sounds rapidly cut off/on while standing near any body of water.  (Sort of sounds like the "whop whop whop" of helicopter blades.) That's not an exhaustive list by any means, but if you want to get an idea of the other issues people have discovered, head over to the discussions and check out the Bug Reports section.  Sure, the game is still playable, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't get some entertainment out of it despite all the times it has made me cross-eyed with rage, but if your'e the kind of person who expects near perfection from their games and is easily annoyed by really obvious bugs, I would avoid this one, for now at least.  Maybe check back in a few weeks or so and see if the game has been patched up some more, but as it stands right now, I can't recommend this game.Specs:  (no overclocking)i7-6700KGTX 107016 GB RAM500 GB SSDSoundBlaster Z

												This is from the perspective of someone who has been a huge fan of theHunter: Classic for many years and have quite a bit of time and money invested in it.Call of the Wild is a beautiful game environment and solid hunting mechanics; which will feel familiar to veteran Classic players and not too daunting for new hunters to the 'series'.I've seen a lot of people ask if this is anything like Cabela's. I would have to say that CotW is FAR superior to Cabela's; but still maintains a 'casual' hunter feel to it. There are still a few launch issues and bugs however, which really should have been ironed out from the Beta before retail release; including some issues that aren't dissimilar to what has or is being experienced in theHunter: Classic (specifically MP issues). Pros: -Gorgeous graphics-Great sound design-Reserves are very well designed and visually interesting.-Dynamic weather system is well implemented.-Smooth animations and weapons feel like they have weight.-Players can jump! This might sound ridiculous to put on a pro's list; but it's one of the biggest features I wanted in Classic.-Stalking animals is MUCH easier. This could also be listed as a Con.-Progression system with XP, Money and Weapon skill, that will keep you striving to improve.-MASSIVE hunting reserves.-Similar game mechanics to Classic, that makes the game familiar for veteran Classic players. -Good tutorial and hint system for new hunters. -Much further render distance for all the long-shot enthusiasts.Cons: -A few UI issues (unable to click some elements, or non-responsive elements)-Experienced a couple of crashes due to entering the System Settings menu. (work-around is to change settings, then restart the game. Another suggestion is to disable cloud-sync in Steam).  -Animals aren't as 'hard' when it comes to Spook range and flee distance from weapon firing. -MP has a few issues. Most noticeably with desync (shooting animals that aren't actually there). -Joining an MP game can spawn you out of bounds, or with 0 health. (This isn't game breaking from my experience as it respawns you near the host. )-Can't quit to Main Menu - only to Desktop.-Can't progress your characters environment/lore/tower unlocks in MP. -No in-depth stats tracking and weapon skill progression compared to Classic. -Progression flow is a bit off (Receiving missions and being advised to use specific callers; which you can't yet unlock due to level or money requirements)-No truRacks system.-Some may find the game too grindy to unlock new weapons and itemsAll in all, I would still recommend this game in spite of its launch issues; if you can tolerate a few bugs. If you are expecting a 100% flawless release, then perhaps give this title a miss until the developers have ironed a few creases out. I'll happily update this review in the near future to accurately reflect any developer changes to anything listed above; or anything new they introduce.I hope this helps!

												Ok so, here I am. One of those guys who's going to give the game a positive review. I've read many of the negative reviews and most of them are actually fact based and have legitimate complaints (instead of people who just hate hunting games saying they hated it.  If you're listening, don't play warcraft if you hate elves and dwarves, and stop playing grand theft auto if you hate cars.)   So, yes, the game has many issues which need to be fixed ASAP and many others which we would all like to see dealt with over time. Having said that,  this game was a great way for me and a close friend to spend some time walking through the woods, when we are too far away to do it in real life. (not to mention, regulations on hunting here are a bit more strict than in game where you can bag 6-7 deer in one evening haha)  The scenery is great, its well done, has a ton of variation, and lots of space. Its also pretty simplistic in its design, not a ton of gimmicky stuff that isn't needed... Have you been way out in the woods before? Its a lot like this game shows. The feel of the firearms is good, the sounds (when they work) are good, the animal behavior is above exceptable, the game offers challenge as well, since you don't start playing, and an hour later have every piece of gear available. I like the "grindy" aspect of it. Maybe others don't but I call this a bonus. The game is quite relaxing and slow paced, perfect for when you need a break from the typical ADHD shooters of our current time or bucket-of-ice-cold-water to the face pvp most online games throw at you.  I like to put this one on the big screen in the living room with a fire going and an ice cold lager, and take my time looking down those fields and wandering the woods. Definitely a relaxing, low stress title here.  So, what needs fixing? well...Plenty.   I'll write more about it in suggestions, and hopefully some Devs can take a look at what I have to say!TL;DR    Yes its not perfect, but with some work it easily could be one of, or even THE greatest hunting game title (depending on what you're after)  Is it worth the cost?  I'm going to say yes, but only with the stipulation that they continue to work on it, and provide the community with more content and bug fixes without asking for more money.EDIT:   wanted to include what i posted in suggestions.Ok, so I've only played about 10 hours so far, but I thought I should write this while the thoughts are fresh in my mind.  I'll start by saying that I gave this a positive review in steam, and suggested people take a closer look at it.  I spent quite a few hours last night having a lot of fun playing multiplayer with a close friend of mine.  We talked a lot on discord and discussed a few of the issues people are complaining about, as well as some of the bugs and issues we encountered ourselves.  I think this game is really good already and potentially will be amazing.  Having said that, here are a few things I would like to draw some attention to (in no particular order);1. Option of "exit to main menu/home screen"  I really think this should have been here already, and many agree.  Exiting to desktop is a bit annoying, especially for people on my friends list who see "mike is playing, mike stopped playing, mike is playing" lol.  Lets add a "quit to main menu"?2. In Multiplayer, only the person hosting is able to interact with the (?) on the map. As far as we could tell last night, only the host is able to fast travel as well. This is a huge disadvantage and also makes no sense. It would be nice to say "hey, lets all meet at the lodge/outpost for a moment and restock and regroup" or something. It can take a while if you get separated to walk all the way to your friend!  Not to mention, wandering up to a landmark or lookout and not being able to do anything, or being unable to build a blind, etc.  Lets make it so anyone can use these things!3. Money.  So, I have no huge issue with this but I wanted to add a few personal points here. I think the money system should be scaled a bit.  I'm going to use $, so please euro players, etc, bear with me (i'm canadian but I'll use USD).  A box of ammunition doesn't cost 300$ in real life.  and the normal hunting rifles a regular person buys (i'm talking AVERAGE here) are maybe 2000$ or even less.  (I bought a browning for 800 once, and it even came with a scope).  I think charging 30,000$ is a bit high. Perhaps have the money earned cut down a bit, and then scale the cost of things for a bit more realism.  I'd suggest 20 rounds of ammunition for lets say 45-50$4.Sound issues.  Some people don't have this, but a few I've spoken to do. I don't know about you but for me, there is nothing worse than waiting an hour for that perfect tag to show up (deer, etc) and lining up your perfect shot and then "silence" when you pull the trigger.  It's quite anticlimactic when that happens. Not to mention the calls sometimes being silent, or rain sounding a bit buggy, etc.  I hope these sound bugs are eliminated soon. Not a deal breaker for me, but should be addressed.5.Here's one I haven't seen anyone mention. Why do female characters run like the flash? Friend of mine literally leaves me in the dust when we're moving together (and yes I triple checked, i'm running, not walking)  She ran about 85% faster than my male character. Is this a bug or intentional? Do male characters get some other bonus like carrying more weight or something? (not being sexist, just asking)  Is there a point in playing as a male when you can essentially speedwalk as a female?6. Wildlife changes.  Bird hunting should be added (and forgive me if it is but I haven't unlocked it)  if you're going to have shotguns in the game, there should be geese, duck, turkey, pheasant...whatever.  As far as I can tell this isn't really a thing. Can anyone confirm? I've not read anything definite so far, but some have told me there is no such gamebirds added. More wildlife would be nice too, but mostly just the bird hunting (a favorite of mine in real life) is something I'd love to see.7.Group activity.  It would be fun in multiplayer to have some quest/challenge that is co-operative. Maybe a party system or something where if 2 people collaborate on a kill, they share the rewards, regardless of who pulled the trigger. 9.I've heard this mentioned before but,  seasons.  Would be kind of interesting if you could make some selections when starting a multiplayer like winter, rain on or off, night only, day only, fall, spring...etc.  Some other maps/terrain variations in general would be nice (sort of goes along with that)  Just vague ideas I'm throwing out here. 10. Firing range, practice. Something like that might be useful for those who have never hunted or shot in real life, or are new to these types of games.   Well, that's all for now, I welcome any comments and bumps.

Game can crash and lock up the pc with loud audio, no 'COTW_F stopped working message'.   This didn't happen for me before 1.1. Happened yesterday to a friend I was in TS with.2.  The Zombie speed bug is still there after you interrogate a lot of tracks, having to select HM then a weapon, to get around it, is a pain.3.  There seems to be a finite amount of tracks, a few times in a long hunt, animals I have shot and killed have left no tracks, it was pure luck I found the body. (I tried using the light in case it was a day/night problem.)4.  UI still clunky, .270 hollow point ammo still locked even with sufficient rifle skill, unlockable Stands... STILL!5.  Animals stuck in trees, rocks and the animation where the animal freezes and does a slow piroutette is hilarious.6.  Animals reacting to callers, regardless of species, if you don't have a certain caller, use anyone, it'll work.  Both predator callers use the same sound file, but there again a lot of animals use the same warning calls... still not fixed.7.  Animals in groups ignoring shots, allowing the entire herd to be killed. (Not sure whether this should be a pro!)PROS:1.  It is very pretty, which is the main theme of all the positive reviews.2.  Positive reviews make a great deal of how realistic and immersive it is, if you have frozen, 'rotating on the spot' animals where you hunt, then this game might be considered realistic!I'll say it again, this could be a cracking game... I'll post more after the next big patch.Another update, 53 hours in, but first, some quotes from positive reviews:'There are still a few launch issues and bugs however, which really should have been ironed out from the Beta before retail release; including some issues that aren't dissimilar to what has or is being experienced in theHunter: Classic (specifically MP issues).It has some buges, but I believe those will be patched soon.'There's a plethora of <10 hours played positive reviews coming out, it's just a shame the IP addresses aren't displayed ;)Ok, on with the review:A few crashes, but not enough to make me give up on it yet, Ooh I'm stubborn!Today's highlights:Thanks to the posts in discussions about how to change map without restarting (Kudos to the OPs), I went to North America.  I had difficulty walking without treading on animals, so different to Hirsch!  I could see for miles and levelled up so quickly, it made me look as though I knew what I was doing. (Which my TS mates know to be untrue.)Problems with North America:Some buildable items don't appear on the map and aren't buildable.Shot some animals which don't leave tracks (this was just before the game crashed.)Some of the animal audio clues are very slow or looped, actually I rather like this, it made me laugh to hear a 10 times slowed whitetail call, talk about a wet F**t!Thank you to the people who've added me and asked me whether to buy it on the strength of my review.  I'm new to this and I'm trying to do it as honestly as I can.Update after day 2:A positive note!I only had one crash on startup and zero crashes whilst ingame.. I believe in giving credit where credit is due and the hotfixes appear to have lessened the crashes for me. (As they did in the beta hotfixes.. so why weren't they included in the release version?)I am, however, amazed by the state in which this game was released... this is the official workaround for being unable to change key bindings ingame:'Disable cloud saving on Steam (Properties -> Updates -> Untick Steam Cloud Synchronization)Go to Documents\Avalanche Studios\theHunter Call of the Wild\Saves open your save folderOpen “keymap.json” with a text editor of your choice (e.g. Notepad)Manually adjust keybindingsSave file and start the game (keeping cloud save disabled until you have started it once)'Quick question... this is a release version and not early access?  If something as simple as keybindings is screwed up, then it doesn't bode well for the game.Ok, into day 2's review:I played this game a lot today, 30 something hours in (including it's older sibling - the beta!)A few observations, it would be nice if:1. I could go to the map and not have a random view nowhere near where my player is, at a scale where I could see where I am.2. Red Deer, Roe Deer and other animals didn't share the same audio for warning calls. (Reported in Beta)3. The hit boxes worked (even some of the EW affiliated tubers made mention of this).4.  I didn't sink into the ground in open fields at night.5. Squirrels and rabbits didn't sound as though they weighed 20 tonnes ingame, they are the loudest animals when they are running around.6. When you brush against foliage ingame, the sound comes from roughly the same direction of that the foliage is in... otherwise it could be a 20 tonne squirrel.In summary... despite all of the above, this could be a cracking game, what's letting it down at the moment is the shooting side of it.  I had great fun running round and unlocking stuff and doing the odd mission, but as an immersive hunting simulator - forget it.Day 1:It's the Beta, stuck animals, COTW_F crashes and, as an added bonus, if you've been a member of the Hunter for a while, you get the chance to buy, with ingame credits, an extra rifle and ghillie suit... hardly a bonus.I'm so disappointed with myself for falling for it yet again, when will I learn?  Answer... when the first DLC comes out.

												This one hurts... I was really looking forward to it, but it lets you down hard. It has the potential to be a really good game, but unfortunately it's way too far from finished. For every reason to play, there is, at least for the moment, two not to. I don't even know where to start, but here goes.The bugs... this game is so broken.Disappearing animals, disappearing tracks, the photo missions are a bloody mess (the patch didn't work), sometimes your scope sights work, at other times it just looks like you're looking through a tube on top of your rifle. Over and above that, I've experienced three complete system crashes. Just not good enough. The walking... oh my good gods, the walking.If you're looking for a game that's more of a hiking simulator than anything else, you've come to the right place!Everything is so bloody far away and while you can fast travel between base camps, you still have to discover them. Walking 4km to a mission is not fun - even if you can shoot a few things along the way. This is especially fun when you've walked more than 3km and your game crashes. Giving me an achievement that I've run an ultra marathon doesn't help either. This isn't called The Marathon Runner. Progression... making me work my♥♥♥♥♥off for something that's worseFirst of all, skill points and perks. Their effects are nominal. You don't actually feel like you've progressed at all. The ability to judge an animal's weight doesn't work, because the developers never really got around to sorting out the whole kg/pound conversion thing just yet. Then, of course, you have to choose whether you want to range your sights, or judge the windage of your shot (the windage often differs significantly from the general wind direction, because, you know, deer farts and stuff). Secondly, the progression of firearms. THIS! I worked my way up to the .338 - they don't say whether it's a .338 Lapua or Winchester. Regardless, both of these cartridges are renowned for their accuracy. Not in this game though. 0 accuracy. 0. Nought. You work your way up to the best (and most expensive) rifle in the game and it can't shoot straight.Lack of contentTwo maps, each with their own animals. But it gets old quickly. The missions are all the same, the amount of weapons are ridiculously small and the "balancing" (I presume) between damage and accuracy just means that one is slightly less crappy than the other. Having said all of this, it does have a few good points. The hunting is fun and it'll keep you entertained for a few hours. The game is beautiful - the terrain is awesome and the animal models are pretty good. It seems that the developers are pretty keen to improve it, but I'm extremely disappointed that it was released in this state. This game is not finished and letting people buy it so that they can help you pick out the bugs is total BS (even though it is an often too common thing these days). Again, this has the potential to be a really great game, but for the moment, I'd steer clear.

												EDIT TO REVIEW:So I've been watching this game closly and the devs are very very active in fixing and tweaking the game. They've fixed some issues I've expressed below so I now have high hopes for this game. It's not perfect but the patching makes me hopeful. My experience with this game:-Decide to try stalking a deer-Follow closely behind on although never getting to see it because it can hear me crouch walking through foliage made of old sun chip bags-Crouch walking for an hour at least, get acheivement for tracking 50 tracks for one animal-Another hour later finally see deer glitch humping a rock, I could walk up to it and it would keep glitching-Decide that wasn't rewarding so move onto another deer-20 minutes later hear one mating call-Crouched and moved toward it-Rinse repeat 50 or so tracks later I have a clear shot-Aim scope, a third grader could hold it more steady-Decide to try prone, my guy must of grabbed a handful of foliage and duct taped it to from of scope-Take a shot from crouch, headshot-Deer runs away like nothing happened-Figured "Well it shouldn't take long to bleed out"-Investigate blood splatter "flesh wound"-Stayed stationary for 10 or so minutes, had cup of coffee-Track blood trail-50 or so blood splatters later decide to let it bleed more-I go to town, shop at the mall, go on real hunting trip, shoot deer in exact spot as on game, it bleeds out within 15, carry deer back to truck, drive home, gut deer, hang meat up, smoke a good amount of it, go to college for 4 years, get married, have kids and realize I left game running, go back to check it-Track 50 more blood splatters, finally find deer-Take another shot, body hit-10 mote blood splatters later finally find deer body, victory-Rifle skill +1-Can't buy anything useful from shop without genociding all deer-Any real hunting equipment you need 40 hours of gameplay to actually get toActual Review:-Weapons: It takes far too long to level up to the point of unlocking a new weapon, and even longer to get the cash for one. It seems like when I earn enough for one weapon I've unlocked the next one and have to choose to earn enough for that one or buy the lower weapon class one. I realize using different weapon classes provides an integrity bonus, for example using a lower calibur bullet on smaller game gets you more cash. I'm not sure if I understand this entirely not being an avid hunter.-Codex: Very bare bones for information. Doesn't quite explain the most important issues like how to use certain equipment and why the highest calibur rifle has an accuracy of 0. Looked for a wikia and didn't find much. But I shouldn't have to use google to have a base understanding of a game.-Callers: Very very useful, almost to a fault. I've been hunting only a few times in the real world and callers have not worked so well for me. It seems like I just sprint through the forest, hear a warning call, use the correct caller and wait. Seems like the other methods of hunting in this game are much more difficult and I find myself using callers to farm money for hours just to buy a new rifle.-Leveling up: Extremely slow leveling progression. I have 35 hours and about 150-200 animals hunted. I'm a total level of 15. Very few skills I can get and very few perks. I understand hunting is a time consuming activity and a simulation should be as realistic as possible, but it seems like grinding levels takes the fun out of it.-Glitching: I've experienced many glitches. I press ESC and it sends me to another reserve, after taking a shot with the perk to stay scoped it shows me down the barrel of the gun instead of scope, serveral several animals are stuck on rocks and trees, [E] Inspect stays until restart of game, certain items requiring 0/0 skill remain locked through entire game, animals remaining upright after death, after coming out of aim it auto spins me 90-180 degrees instantly and animals shot over ~300m don't take off running.It is a beautiful looking game and has a lot of good aspects to it. But the gameplay seems underdeveloped.

												Give it a chance, I actually refunded this after 2 hours but something drew me right back.I have played just about every hunting game since the mid 90's and out of all those games, this has the magic of some of the very best. (BTW - you can disable most HUD popups and the "Deer icons" are only tutorial, don't be like me and think it was a full time feature!)For an "Arcadey theHunter" - as many (included myself) branded it - it certainly does not feel like it when you dig deep. It is not a shooting gallery, dont expect deer to just wander past you - in some aspects its even more realistic than Classic.For example -- View distance is FINALLY increased meaning that looking into the distance is actually important now.- Night hunts - call them unethical all you want, but get out there with your headtorch under the stars, the moonlight glowing on the ground and the beautiful sounds of owls hooting in the distance makes it an unforgetable experience. I actually prefer to hunt during this time.- Animals actually have a more believable routine (Wild boar are rarely seen  out in the open during the day, only venturing out after dusk etc) You also have feeding spots and bedding areas which they return to.- Graphics - wow - honestly I cannot work out how some people have slated the graphics as merely "OK" because the visuals are simply mind blowing at 4k on ultra. It is so inviting you actually want to explore the (HUGE) map. Walking speed also feels more realistic and not just a geriatric shuffle.- The little things - bushes actually make noise now so it effects how you stalk your prey. The grass becomed flattened behind you and animals, leaving a very realistic looking path. An IN GAME mission journal. The majority of threatened animals can harm you if cornered. Animal tracks last longer than a few hours. The sounds are beautiful, the animations are fluid and there is ample map to explore and discover.One of the best things is the sense of progression this game gives you. You do not start with all the gear, you have to unlock it with ingame money and levelups so there is an actual goal to play towards. The downsides are - - Generic deer antlers - I can only hope the devs listen to the pleas of fans and change this.- Some optimization issues for some but they said from the start, this is a HIGH QUALITY game - do not expect older machines to max it out.It is far from pefect, needs a bit of polish and bug fixes but my god, its a fun game. Whine all you want about it "not being a finished game" - while it may not have the amount of animals or the sophisticated TruRACS system, its certainly giving me alot more enjoyment than classic ever did.

												**This Review has been Updated****Update: Since the update, I have noticed that the small animals(ie, rabbits and squirrels) are no longer wearing rain jackets, and thus no longer sound like they are running through empty bags of Doritos. However, when tracking a moose that I shot, I completely lost the blood trail randomly. I don't know if this is a new feature or what, but the moose circled around in the area of an old trail, and while I found plenty of tracks, I found no more blood trail which is key to finding a wounded animal and keeping on the right track. That could have been an issue on my end, I suppose, and I'll have to look into this a bit more in order to determine if this is some sort of bug. Also, it is obvious that the crouch-walking works better now in this new update, and you get spotted less frequently when you are crouched and moving. On the downside though, you walk painfully slower when traveling this way. But I suppose that's supposed to be realistic, so that's fair.**Is it worth buying at this point? That's for you to decide. There are both positives and negatives about the current state of this game, keep reading. Starting with the Positives about the game: The settings are great. From the visuals in the scenery, to the audio with raindrops and the wind blowing through the leaves, the background really is pretty stunning. You don't have a wide variety of animals to shoot at this point, but those that you can they look very well done. The animals also sound really good, and often behave like wild animals. If you don't get good shot placement, you can very much rely on having to track a wounded animal for some time until you can either finally put it down, or it eventually succumbs to it's injuries. The little stories in singleplayer and missions are also pretty neat. And on to the Negatives: Why do the squirrels and rabbits sound like they are wearing little little rainjackets when they run around? While the game animals sound fairly normal as they walk through the grass and brush, the smaller critters sound like they are wearing plastic as they romp about the trees and meadows. Nothing breaks the immersion as you're sighting in on a large buck as you suddenly hear a pair of squirrels wearing windsuits dashing about the boulder you've perched on to take your shot. And as you suddenly look around to see what is going on around you, your buck notices the movement and shoots off like a rocket into the safety of the forest as you silently curse the creators of these squirrels. Also, at random times, the game suddenly decides that it's done playing nice. And your leisurely stroll through the meadow as you search for a black bear takes a sudden turn as you notice that you are now walking in slow motion. So you switch for your tracker to a rifle so you can walk a bit faster for a bit, but soon you're still forced to a virtual crawl as your walk becomes visibly slower. And so you have to restart the game. Sometimes, you come across an animal that is stuck in some way. Sometimes it is stuck between a tree and a rock, for example. At other times, it's stuck in a loop, walking or running in a sort of circle. And so you fire a shot at the stuck animal. Sometimes you'll kill it. Sometimes you'll just scare it, and it will run faster even though it's still stuck. Now and again, it'll take one hit, but it won't kill it, even though it just runs faster and faster and as you shoot at it over and over again-at times you'll see the shot take effect and it stumbles to the ground-it'll get back up and refuse to die. And you'll have to restart the game because you're never going to kill it. Sometimes you'll shoot a stuck animal, and no matter how point-blank you shoot it, the bullets magically fail to hit their intended target. Other times you'll clearly and visibly hit the animal, and it'll eventually run off. But when you come up to find the blood trail, you'll see that there is no blood. Even though the animal clearly fell the ground and got back up to run away, there's no blood. You may have hit it three or four times, and there's no blood trail. And when you eventually give up, you suddenly notice that you don't see animal tracks anymore, and if you fire a shot at something, it magically misses(although it does expend ammo). Sometimes this can be fixed by fast traveling to an outpost. You might think that the negatives outweigh the positives. Or vice versa. And that's up to you decide. For me, even though the game is currently frustrating at it's present state, I still enjoy it. The visuals are well-done, the animal movements are excellent, etc. But it's also frustrating and a little buggy. The immersion breaks at points(especially when you or a small animal moves through the brush and grass), the game crawls at times, and you sometimes can't hit what your aiming at even if you could literally touch the animal you're shooting at. Would I recommend this game? Yes, with the caveats that this game is currently buggy, but I do believe that the developers will get it fixed. The makers of this game have done well with other games in the theHunter line, and there's no reason to think they won't get these problems fixed. For that reason, I do recommend this game.

												tl;dr  I like it, but it is a $30 USD Open Beta at the moment.The things that work in the game are good.  It feels a lot like theHunter Classic from several years back, but without subscription fees. That's the best thing about the game.  There's more here at launch than the Classic game had at launch, which is also a plus.The problem is that it is absolutely riddled with bugs, poor design decisions, and a lack of certain features which made the Classic game fun to play for so many years.  It easily could have used another 6 months to a year of development before release. Or at the very least, released it as an Early Access game, because that's essentially what it is at this point in time. The Good:  1. The hunting is great.  Aside from a few bugs and other minor annoyances.2. Graphics are really nice.  Easy to immerse yourself in the world. 3. No subscription fee. I've been waiting for a subscription-less Hunter ever since the Classic game released.4. No microtransactions or other real money purchases. All the weapons and equipment are able to be bought in game without having to pay real money for them.5. Xbox One controller support.  Seriously this is great. With as much walking and creeping around that you have to do, it's nice to just use the controller and sit back relaxed.  And you can still use the mouse to shoot if you want. I've been using the controller to move, and the mouse for precision shooting. 6. The game is self-contained. No more having to go to theHunter website to setup your hunt and launch. The Bad:1. Bugs. Bugs everywhere.  From sounds not being played, to hunting structures not allowing you to build them, to animals getting stuck in the scenery, it is absolutely riddled with bugs. 2. Progression system feels poorly designed.   It takes forever to acquire enough "experience" to unlock new weapons and gear.  13 hours into the release version, I'm level 9 and have unlocked 1 gun, a bullet type, and maybe a caller?  The perks and skills system could use a reworking as well.   Apparently at least one perk doesn't seem to work for anyone.3. No global leaderboards or competitions.  What's the point of harvesting a great trophy animal, if you can't see where it ranks compared to other people, or enter it into a competition? The competitions are one thing that really gave the Classic Hunter such longevity. 4. The missions.  One of the first missions you get is to "photograph" a deer for a woman's book.  I want to hunt, not take screenshots. Adding to the frustration is that it seems like you have to do this in a very specific area, and at a very specific distance from the deer. Apparently you get more photography missions later, that get even more specific.  Maybe this could have been more fun if they actually modeled the camera like a real world DSLR set up for wildlife shooting. Instead the game's camera is basically the HUD removed, and replaced with a grid. No zoom controls that I could see.  So basically your smart phone from 5 years ago had more features in the camera than this one.I'm pretty much ignoring the missions right now unless I accidentally trigger one.Could be Better:1. A lot of things could use a bit of rework or tweaking.  One thing I'd like to see added is more fast travel options. If I build a hunting stand somewhere, I'd like the option of fast traveling to it like you can do with the outposts. If the devs don't abandon the game, and continue working on it, it has a lot of potential.  I mostly like what is here now, and I could potentially spend a lot of time with this game.  It wouldn't take a lot to flip the thumbs down to a thumbs up. Mostly fix the glaring bugs and maybe tweak a few of the systems in game. That's not asking much.  I just have a hard time fully recommending the game in its current state.

												An early game review:So i think most people reviewing this negatively are being way dramatic about the state of the game. It's a bit buggy but it's nothing that cant be fixed with a good few patches.This game is one of the most beautiful games out there right now, runs fine for me personally, quite well really.Points starting from bad to good:- Yeah there are bugs, for sure. Menu buggitude, people sayin bears are bugged a bit too. And whenever i would harvest an animal my game settings would get reset. Im hopeful these things can get fixed pretty easily tho. As far as stuck animals go, as a game developer, problems like this can be really difficult to solve and are common in a ton of games. I think they should maybe look into it but im not going to blame them too hard if i see the occasional stuck animal. i only encountered one stuck animal in my play time and it was just a dinky rabbit.Edit: After some more time i have noticed a few more stuck animals which is unfortunate but not game breaking really, id say youd end up seeing one stuck animal per 2 hours or so of gameplay. Some more bugs as well such as scope clipping and bugged animation on scope zoom, some fps drops wen tracking animals long distances using the phone thing, and game freezing occasionally, sometimes recovering other times not. - Some people talking about the game being too easy and too many animals but id like to know what game they were playing because for me, trying to get a good shot and then not being able to and spooking the animals and then having to track em down for like an hour without seeing anything,, i dont think the game was too overflowing with animals. However there are a lot more animal calls sometimes it seems, which i think is fine and turning off the audio visualzation is good idea as well.Edit - A little more detail on this: Sometimes there can definitely be quite a few animal calls, a lot more than were in theHunter classic. Personally i dont really have a problem with this as they are just calls, and they arent distracting if you have the vocal visualizations off. While running around you are likely to never actually see any of the animals calling unless you run into a field where there may be a few animals grazing (but this doesnt feel unrealistic to me at least) but it does hark on to my point about sound where animal calls are louder than they should be really. Maybe putting the calls on a seperate audio slider or something. Its also important to NOTE: if you hunt out an area and scare off animals its totally quiet out there. So in all, i still dont feel there are "too many" animals as the likelyhood of encountering one is not astronomically high or anything.- I've seen some people say its lacking content? But from what i can tell the maps are huuge and vary pretty good in the areas and there are a fair number of animals to hunt right now, as well as a fair amount of weaponry. The game is not like a full price AAA release, its half that in fact, and, if you were to compare it to theHunter classic, this game is a bargain. If you wanted to do any of the stuff in this game in classic youd be paying for a membership and paying real money like $5 per weapon. The game has plenty of content for $30 with more to come in dlcs. -This game however, does not have a lot of the features that classic has in terms of competitions and leaderboards and community. I think this is intentional and likely to stay that way. Both games serve a purpose, and the purpose of this game is not to be exactly like the last one, but a more standalone experience not tied down to microtransactions and a separate launcher with community stuff and accounts and all that jazz. This may turn some of the more hardcore hunters off, and if it does, then i dont think this game is for you.- Does not have free look to detach look direction from walk direction. That would be a veryyy nice thing to have and i dont know why it isnt in already.- Uses a progression tree in terms of weapon perks and various skills. This is a highly subjective way of doing it but i think it is a fine way to do it. I dont think its anything special and is highly debatable but i dont think it should be a turn off. It just allows for progression of the game and your character, which by the way, theres just about no character choice options... this easily seems like one of the most underdeveloped things. but eh.- Sound is very immersive and well realized. Ive seen some people complain about the sound being bad somehow but this is crazy talk if you ask me. Maybe im just not hardcore enough of a hunter to really understand but i think some people are just babies.Edit: while i still think sound is very good, some things ive noticed after more time are music cutting out randomly, bear calls being cut short, and sounds of russling and animal calls being a bit too loud.- A quick graphics review: The game is gorgeous. Hands down the best nature ive ever seen in a game. If i had to gripe about graphics at all as a hardcore graphics enthusiast, shadows are pretty blocky, but they can get away with this because there is a ton of foliage to break up the shadows so that you wont notice unless you reeallyyy look at them. Still a higher res shadow option could be nice, but i think they used resources freed by using lower quality shadows for more impactful features elsewhere. The clouds if you look at them too hard are obviously just moving textures in the sky but whatever really the game is about nature not clouds and they look pretty good when not viewed under scrutiny. Water reflections are a bit low res.. i know reflections can be intense but at least an option for some higher quality reflections would be nice. Also about reflections, and this can be an issue with water effects in a lot of games, around edges of objects where water is in the background there is a weird halo around them, not a super big deal but very noticable. No option for anti aliasing??? this is a weird one but i guess there is AA applied somewhere at least, maybe tied to quality setting, but not cool at any rate. That being said, i havent really had any issues with aliasing, its not a jag fest like some games are. And you would think this would be too with all the foliage. And don't even get me started on the foliage, its so dense and detailed and even reacts to animals and players to the point where animals leave paths through the grass as they walk, easily the best foliage ive ever seen in a game. Overall, Beautiful game.I think that covers most things.Conclusion:The game is pretty good for the price. A must have if you like walking simulation and hunting experiences.Perhaps hold off for a month or two until some of the more glaring bugs and finicky-ness is sorted out if that kind of thing bothers you.

theHunter: Call of the WildGameplayIt needs to be out of the way first, theHunter: Call of the Wild is about hunting wildlife. If you are okay with that, then the game is going to be pretty much what you expected. I played the original Hunter quite a while back and I was not able to get into it for some reason. theHunter: Call of the Wild seems much more streamlined than the previous game which was pretty inviting for me as well as new player to the series. theHunter: Call of the Wild puts you in the boots of a Hunter in a huge open world with the prospect of hunting virtual wildlife. That is pretty much all the story that is present in the game, because even after the narrator telling you a few lines and giving you some quests, it is pretty vague. Do not go in expecting a brilliant narrative adventure out of this game. Now, how does the actual hunting holds up.For the most part, the hunting in theHunter: Call of the Wild is pretty solid. You get all kinds of tools at your disposal to hunt down the surprising less diverse wildlife. From noise maker to sprays to attract your prey towards a location and then putting a bullet through their lungs, that is the game. theHunter: Call of the Wild does falter in the skill tree it uses to unlock all these fancy tools and you really need to grind your way by murdering quite a lot of fauna.  This requires a lot of patience and time and might frustrate some players. You can unlock Far Cry 3 like towers which show you points of interests on that particular part of the map. The gun recoils are nice and feel quite good to use.Don’t expect to go in all bullet blazing though like a Call of Duty game. theHunter: Call of the Wild requires you to be patient and wait for the creature to be at a perfect position when you take the shot. The animal can even run away wounded and you will have to follow its blood trail to track and hunt it down. theHunter: Call of the Wild is at its best in these moments, I remember trailing a rare bear for some time following a blood trail it left and finally catching it a water body it came near to drink. It keeps you immersed in these moments and truly feels like something special. The wildlife is also very quick to react and they make the world a living breathing one. But in theHunter: Call of the Wild you’re basically like a god. It is nigh impossible for a creature to kill you unless you stand right in front of a bear. Even the fall damage from a high outpost isn’t enough to actually kill you. I felt bad for these poor creatures who were just waiting to be preyed upon. There is no food requirement, nothing that can force you to tense up. You can go hunting in the night and there will be literally no other danger. While there is plenty of wildlife to hunt, the diversity is pretty low. More often than not you will run into yet another bear or deer and it gets very repetitive after a while. You also have to walk a lot which is expected but it won’t please most of the audience. It is not helped by the fact that theHunter: Call of the Wild is extremely buggy. I can’t recall how many times a creature clipped through the trees, my bullets just whizzed past the animal’s lungs without hurting it and the constant crashes are enough the annoy anyone out of their wits. While the multiplayer works fine when playing with friends, it seems that this game is not really made for it. Too many hunters spoil a game and it is very much true here. VisualsVisually theHunter: Call of the Wild looks stunning. From the god rays of the sun to the gentle breeze flowing through the forest, it is one of the prettiest games I’ve played. The animal models are also really stunning and the game just takes your breath away quite some times with the beautiful vistas it presents. There is a fair amount of visual pop in and there are some really hilarious visual glitches which might break your immersion sometimes but overall it is pretty beautiful. What is a letdown though are the human models in multiplayer. They look like someone put a bunch of dolls in a jungle and that does help the game.SoundExcellent. From the animals sounds to just the rain pattering on the leaves, everything is done beautifully. The only trouble is when you walk through a water body which is when your shoes make more sounds than a bear who is ready to mate. But overall it has an excellent sound package.OverallI can’t help but like theHunter: Call of the Wild. It has its problems and it does certainly feel like an early access game but if you want a proper hunting game, theHunter: Call of the Wild should be your choice. It needs some polish and more content but as it stands, it is a solid hunting game which sports outstanding visuals and excellent sound design. It is not for everyone though and you should keep that in mind if you are purchasing this game. 												This is the most beautiful game I have played in some time. I would say that the game is quite modestly priced for what it provides, but it is clearly a hunting experience more than a hunting game - so it's not going to be a game for everyone.Headshots at low calibre "bug"Most of the negative reviews I see claim "bugs" for what is actually how ballistics work in the real world. Example: lower calibre headshots will often not kill an animal. Many of the animals use their heads for fighting for goodness sake! I have (in real life) shot goats in the head and have the animal up and leave. The skull on many animals is very thick and therefore you're aiming for the heart/lungs.Negatives:- The Skill/Perk/XP/Points system is insane. Obviously, this is a leftover from the game having P2W/F2P mechanics which I am glad they dropped. But it's left us with a pretty terrible and confusing system that is incredibly convoluted. It doesn't rise to the point of a negative reivew, but it's close for me.- Multiplayer is a little buggy at times. Not overly so, and it's been acknowledged by the devs and they're clearlying targeting patches to this. It's still very playable and enjoyable.- The range of weapons available is pretty low.- The amount of equipment available to upgrade you weapons was much lower than I was expecting. While some of this would be quite "game-y", I was expecting being able to customize your weapons and equipment more according to how you wanted to play.Positives:+ The game is the most beautiful game I have played a in a long time, hands down. They're using dynamic color grading, volumetric lights, dynamic shadows... I mean just everything and the results are superb!+ The map(s) are staggering in their scale and attention to detail. They're hand made and they are huge. Much bigger than ArmA.+ The performance of the game on a high-end PC is excellent. Don't expect to run at ULTRA on current gen hardware, and don't be mad about that! The game is made in such a way that it's going to grow with hardware and that's great.+ The pacing of the game is really superb. It strikes an excellent balance between requiring patience and keeping something happening to the player.+ Post kill review screen. You see the pose, entry, and damage modelling for what you killed. Absolutely amazing and makes your kill "story" fantastic.+ Tracking is exciting and the classic "easy to do hard to master". This is a well designed mechanic that leads to excellent pacing.ConclusionIf you are looking for an arcade game, this is not for you. But if you are looking for a hunting game this is a fantastic find. Even better with friends! It's modest price is worth is alone for how beautiful the terrain is to explore.

A visual representation of where my view on this game is at the moment. I don't recommend  | I recommend[--------------------------//-|--------------------------]Pros:- Jumping! brilliant feature! Having the ability to jump up onto rocks above open terrain, go prone and wait for unsuspecting prey is a brilliant feature, personally i much prefer looking at terrain for firing positions than using the pre determined structures.- Not having to use your Huntermate to track animals, although it does aid you with an easy to follow cone of direction, you can quite happily walk with your rifle in your hands and track animals which helps dramatically in reducing the time to take the shot, nothing worse than cresting dead ground to find the animal standing mere metres away, with only your phone in your hand.- Having Need zones on the map - whether it be drinking, sleeping  or eating, you are given a time period in which animals of that type will use these need zones,which helps dramatically at ambushing prey and also giving them a less random feel, they live somewhat structured lives.- A few different ammo types per weapon, allows you to pick and choose which type of arrow or round you would prefer to use, Softpoint or Polymer.- Easy to see and understand unlockable skills, this gives an RPG feel to the game as you feel you are progressing toward something, it also gives you the choice in which areas you would like to progress, whether it be stalking or ambushing, and perks for the type of weapons you use most.- Vast expanse of land to hunt on, this game truly does feel vast with two large reserves to hunt on, both with different landscapes.- The sheer amount of animals on each reserve is staggering and i doubt you have to go particular far in any direction from any position in order to find them wandering around.- Animals regularly herd together, the most i've seen so far was about 30 odd whitetails wandering together at the foot of a valley, it truly was a sight to see.- Hunting animals in the same area means animals will start to avoid that area until it has "cooled down", animals with their skittish nature will avoid areas in which they feel threatened, you will still see animals in these areas just less of them, and the more you hunt in the same spot the less animals will wander into it.- When walking through particular thick vegetation/trees you hear the sound of your nylon jacket, which is incredibly immersive, however rabbits running through the same vegetation appear the make the same noise, i didnt know rabbits were made of nylon (i will admit that after several years of neglecting ear defense this may just be that my hearing is shot and that the two sounds appear to me as the same sound)- There is a guide available by Daniel which shows you how to make your game less blurry and sharper, im enjoying the game more now that i have wiped the slober out of my eyes.- No microtransactions - probably the biggest selling point of this game.- Heart rate and stances effecting weapon sway, this prevents you from being able to run and gun accurately (not that you would neccesarily want to but a good game mechanic to have)- When in the prone position grass and foliage infront of you inhibits sight picture on target, personally i love this, it requires you to either crawl forward to flatten the grass then crawl back in order to optomise your firing postion, or move to a spot where grass wont effect your sight. - The ability to turn off tutorials / mission system / multiplayer nametags / downed animal highlight / spotting outline / audio clue visualization / spatial tracking cone / Points of interest / need zone icons / track effects. Turning everything off gives you the ability to hunt with your own hearing and sight.- Animals leave "channels" in long grass and brush, this helps when stalking or chasing down a wounded animal as an almost perfect trail is left behind.Cons:- Graphics, the graphics are OK but are incredibly hard to run for those with dated PCs, i would go as far to say it is heavily unoptimised. Even with the ability to max any modern released game you will be pushing 30 - 60 FPS with medium/high settings in which the foliage will look less than realistic.- The horrible grind to unlock weapons/lures/etc in the shops - you have to harvest an outrageous amount of animals in order to unlock even the most simple lures or weapon of choice, i feel you should be able to buy any of the kit from get go.- Animals very rarily spook, you can shoot and harvest one only to walk a short distance and repeat, gunshots/running for the most part dont have a very large spook radius.- Fast traveling is virtually non existent which is a pain as you have to take time to travel to need zones or particular favourite spots, the ability to put down tents in TheHunter classic sorted this problem.- No ability to errect your own structures, such as tree stands, 360 stands, ground hides etc, the fact that TheHunter classic has this feature yet the new edition doesn't is a real shame, it feels like a real step backwards.- By Comparison to TheHunter classic there is very little equipment/weapons/lures available, which i hope with potential future DLC will be expanded upon, again a step backwards.- The game states that clothes do not have any effect on whether animals can detect you, this again is a feature that is included in theHunter classic with the addition of Ghillie suits, 3D sneaky clothing etc.- The bugs although not game destroying are rather annoying and with some fairly simple bugs i am astounded that this game was released with them, and that after days after release they still persist is mind boggling.- According to the games sound indicator, you give the same amount of sound crawling slowly as you do running.- No ability to range your rifle to anything other than the pre determined 100m.Overall i feel this game is headed in the right direction but as it currently stands lacks some pretty major components of a hunter game, i feel a mixture between this and TheHunter Classic would be ideal, bring back some of those core gameplay elements whilst also bringing in better optimisation and bringing the grind feeling down to a nice enjoyable level and giving the player more freedom on what to hunt from the get go.Having said all that i still feel a burning urge to make this review even longer and do a side by side comparison of the two games which would show you just many features/gameplay aspects have been removed for the sake of improving the graphics, there are so many!

												Just hit 84 hours, and I think it's time to stop.This game looks incredible, I've found myself taking tons of screenshots, especially for kills I was proud of. Let me be clear here, I don't like hunting, I don't agree with hunting, but this game is SO good that I've put 84 hours into it. The positives outnumber the negatives, but unfortunately the game has one whopping failure. So the game itself looks incredible, I've found myself reminiscing about holidays I've been on due to the realism and immersivety. The sounds fit in well with the setting (even if a few things could be worked on) The maps are huge and have some incredible points of interest that have clearly had a lot of time spent on them. The animals are difficult to hunt and you have to be mindful of many different ways in which you play in order to stalk an animal and get up and close. This is great! Going from scaring everything off in the vicinity to being able to get within 20m of a deer feels like great progress. The guns seem fairly priced, the missions tell you stories that are pretty interesting. You can choose whether or not you want to do a mission - you'd probably spend a good 50 hours walking round and exploring if killing isn't your thing. The game really is incredible. However, 84 hours in I'm here typing a review for a game that I don't recommend. So let me explain. About 20 hours into the game a friend asked me if it was worth buying, and I told them absolutely. 5 minutes later, my game crashes. My entire system crashes and I have to restart my PC manually. Frustrating, a waste of ammo and time, but no big deal. I reload the game, 5 minutes later, it crashes again. I get the frozen screen, sound loop, I can't alt-f4, I can't Ctrl-alt-delete. Again, I have to manually restart my computer. Turns out it's not just me getting this issue, so with the help of the discussions I try what seemed like 3000 different settings changes just to see if the game is playable. Next time I start up the game, I get 4-5 hours out of it then stop playing, seemed like something had worked. Load up the game again, crashes within 30 minutes. To this day I am still dealing with crashes that seem to have no correlation to any setting, any part of the map, any animal, anything. I've changed so many settings at this point that I'm literally just playing inbetween crashes and every now and then it'll crash so many times in such a short space of time I just give up.This game is literally incredible. I've had crashes ever since 16 hours and yet I've still put up with it up until now. But I cannot recommend this game. It's not badly priced, but this game desperately needed to be released as an alpha or beta. It's just not ready. There are some other bugs (floating guns, weird arm twisty thing, animals getting stuck, rocks killing you for absolutely no reason) but these do not break the game. They're few and far between and they're absolutely bearable. Sitting at my PC for 2 hours and having a game crash 30 times within that time frame is absolutely soul destroying. TO SUM UPIf you're patient, love hunting, fancy a walking simulator or even a fantastic hunting sim, then maybe give it a shot. If you want the game to run smoothly and want to play with friends, really really avoid this game. 84 hours and I don't think I'll be launching this game any time soon. I will say, the developers seem hard working and eager to fix the issues but this game was clearly rushed and isn't in a fit state to be released yet. I really hope they can fix it soon because it's such a great game, and has such great potential.

												This game definitely wasn't ready for release. It's a (pretty bad) beta at best.After reading on the forums that Stefan, one of the developers, refuses to acknowledge one of the most game-breaking bugs (see below) and closes threads, I decided to request a refund.GraphicsThe game is pretty gorgeous looking, that's for sure. Good textures, day/night cycle, dynamic weather, wind moving leaves, grass, etc.I did experience a few minor issues though, like clouds flickering, the handheld occasionally being shown without its display (just the frame) or rain falling right through the roof of a deer stand (how there's still devs in 2017 not paying attention to something like that is beyond me).SoundSounds are very inconsistent in quality. Some sound very realistic with high production quality, others just sound terrible, with static noise at the beginning and/or end of the sound sample (at least when playing with headphones this was easily perceivable).I also repeatedly had issues with sounds ending abruptly (like animal calls or birds chirping) or stuttering, or ambient sounds like wind changing way too fast.Obviously issues like that are constantly breaking someones immersion.InterfaceThe menus are buggy, with buttons not always reacting to clicks. Some options like mouse sensitivity are also a pain to use, since you can only increase/decrease the value by clicking arrows to the left or right. There's no slider or a way to type in a value directly. Annoying, especially if the game doesn't save the settings properly and you have to re-do them the next time you launch the game. There's also no way to go back to the main menu -- you have to quit and restart the game for that (no joke).Several HUD elements don't scale properly when playing on a 16:10 screen. For example, the compass is oval, and markers on the map are oval as well. I suspect people with widescreen-monitors like 21:9 will be affected by this as well.There's also graphical glitches on the map, like terrain textures that aren't properly stitched together, and map overlays that are only partially visible.You can also disable certain aspects of the HUD (like tutorial hints or point of interest markers) or change how animal tracks are being visualized. Sometimes HUD elements can get stuck on your screen or behave strangely if you change the settings and don't restart the game afterwards.Animal AII'm not an animal expert, so I can't talk too much about this topic. But at least on two occasions, after firing a shot, deer ran away, just to come back several minutes later, walking right towards me, coming as close as 10 meters and not notice me at all. Well, I doubt any real animal would do that, unless they are suicidal.There's also reports of animals getting stuck, but I haven't seen that myself in game.Shooting/gunplayShooting seems weird. First I thought I'm doing something wrong, like missing vital organs, since I couldn't even kill non-moving small game from less than 50 meters. I then read in another review that someone was testing the shooting on stuck animals, and had to hit them with up to 6 rounds to kill them, from only a few meters away.A hunting game with broken gun mechanics. Awesome.PerformanceI'm on Windows 7 with an Intel i5-3570K (3.4 GHz, 4 cores, 4 threads) and a Radeon RX 470 (4 GB VRAM). I maxed out all graphics settings, only turned off motion blur. Resolution was set to 2560 × 1600 to reduce flickering of the foliage (native screen resolution is 1920 × 1200).I didn't measure the frames per second, but it was around 30. Which in my book is okay for a slow-paced game like this.ControlsMouse sensitivity is annoyingly low when using binoculars or scopes, even when set to 100 in the settings (the maximum). Maybe it's on purpose to make shooting more difficult, but then at least exclude the binoculars from that 'mechanic'.One severe issue is that you can't walk slowly when using keyboard & mouse, meaning your noise level is always at max when moving, no matter if you're standing, crouching or prone. For comparison, I tested it with my Xbox gamepad and it's fine there, but why would I play a first person hunting game on the PC with a controller?Now, as mentioned at the top of the review, several people have pointed out that issue on the forums, but it seems the developers just try to ignore it and refuse to acknowledge this being a major problem. Which led me to requesting a refund. Because it's bad enough to release a game in a state like this, but then trying to silence or ignore issues... I refuse to support stuff like that.If they fix all these issues (and there's a bunch more I didn't experience personally or forgot to mention) I'll gladly purchase this game again, but until then I recommend everyone to wait and see if the devs get their **** together.

												It definitely has its issues, mostly related to bugs and some optimization issues, but I've had a lot of fun with the game.  I have no history with the series or hunting games in general really, but I find this game to be incredibly relaxing and immersive.  The visuals and sounds are awesome as well as you watch day shift to night and storms suddenly roll in with high winds and heavy rain.  If you are on the edge it might be worth waiting a bit for another patch or two to roll in and see if it fixes some of the bigger issues, however I took the dive myself despite seeing quite a few negative reviews and don't regret it.Pros:- Great visuals- Immersive sound design- It could just be because this is my introduction to his type of game, but it was a thrill listening for and tracking down animals to kill.  I look forward to some more difficult targets that will require more time.- Feels welcoming to players newer to this style of game with a bit more casual presentation.  This of course could be looked at negatively to veterans of this type of game or theHunter Classic.- Speedy loading times.  I don't even have a SSD, but this game loads from the title screen into the game world very quickly which surprised me considering how large the map is.- Various challenges, quests, and lore discovery locations are sprinkled throughout the map, giving some extra activities outside of general hunting.- The two hunting reserve maps are massive in sizeCons:- The biggest issue right now is that with mouse and keyboard controls you have little to no control over the speed of your movement in each of the stances (walking, crouching, prone).  If you have a controller and test the movement out on that, you'll notice with analog control you can move the stick varying amounts to control your speed and subsequently the amount of noise you make.  Considering how important it is to try and remain silent in a hunting game, this is a pretty big issue at the moment.  Either controller movement needs to have that disabled and rework the amount of noise each stance makes, or keyboard needs an keybinding to slow your pace to a level that makes minimal sound.- While I've had no crashes (Update: I have experienced my first crash, so this does seem to be a relevant issue for many players), I have had a performance bug which was causing framerate to drop significantly when I was tracking an animal's footprints a lot.  Having too many of these tracking markers will cause the framerate to drop after opening the map or looking at your Huntermate device.  It would fix itself by either putting away the Huntermate or if you killed the tracked animal and collected your trophy.- Semi annoying menu bug that doesn't let you back out of the menu with escape unless the mouse is hovering over one of the items on the side.- A few of the animals I've shot seemed like it should have been a clean kill, but they would somehow get away with just a minor wound and run off.  More often than not I found success with my shots though.- Animal AI was a bit wonky on at least one occasion with a fox that clearly should have been trying to run away, but instead was running circles around me like a friendly pet dog or something.  Perhaps it was being aggresive and trying to attack or something, but it seemed a bit bizarre with it essentially giving me an easy kill.- Right now it is limited to 12 different animals.  These do have variations to discover, but it would be nice to see some small game targets and birds as well.  I'm assuming we'll see this added down the line at some point when they add some of the planned free and paid DLC content.- The menus ui and control of them in general just feels like it needs a rework as they look and feel like a placeholder that has been in the game since an earlier state.  There are also some issues with the controls when managing your storage where it just seems to completely break when in that particular menu and you have to back out and open it back up to do anything.

shortage of those.The gamebreaking ones to me were:In Multiplayer only the host can unlock map objects, such as hunting stands / outposts (important one, they allow fast travel)Animals get stuck, from my 12 hour experience i would say i have seen 1 in 8 getting stuck, mostly on edges or rocks with bears being a big outlier as i have seen 1 in 4 of them getting stuck.The UI design is unintuitive, being unable to exit to menu and aspecially when it comes to loading ammo/scopes onto a weapon, it's also impossible to read some of the descriptions as the text moves offscreen, and in quite a few cases i saw what i can only describe as a alpha/beta-like placeholder text for some of the ammo/scopes.Some minor issues/bugs i had were:Some crashes when tabbing out and back into the game, i fixed this by adding the "/Borderless" in the steam launch options.Sometimes got a bug with my scope being off center forcing me to restart the game, the adjustment ontop of the scope itself became my crosshair, unequipping etc didn't fix it sadly.In Multiplayer when another player jumps its heard across the map, i suppose this might be an engine issue as it also happened in the previous hunter game with someone reloading.When you fatally hit an animal they sometimes do this weird freeze for up to 1 second and then start to ragdoll, i would love to see this changed / fixed so that you feel more feedback from the bullet impact and it kinda just looks awkward as it is currently.Animals don't spook enough from gunshots sometimes it feels asif they don't even hear the gunshot, i've been able to shoot up to 3 animals ocassionally before they even started getting spooked, i would like to see the range that animals get spooked by gunshots increased.Animals don't seem to interact with eachother, i would've hoped they would introduce something like this, i believe they added something similar to classic with the introduction of wolves so it would be nice if this could be added eventually.And finally theres just too many animals on Layton district, i would prefer it if they were a bit more rare or more easily spooked just recently i shot 5 bears within 10 minutes and before that about 3 within 4 minutes, one of which was stuck underneath a bridge, although Hirschfelden seems fine.It's also too easy to spot an animal by zooming in on where its call came from, it feels
